Will Price Home Posts Projects Notes

ARRAYS

Array’s are declared using the syntax:

type [] name = new type [size]

Where type is a data type, like int or float and name is the name of the array. Finally, the size is the number of elements in the array.

An example:

// Array of 10 integers to enter ages into.
int [] ages = new int [10]

Initially after defining an array, it will be empty, the elements have no defined values. To set up an array, it’s usually best to fill it with something, lets say 0s.

for (int i = 0; i < ages.length; i++) {
  age[i] = 0;
}

OBJECTS

Objects essentially pack up a set of variables and functions into a data structure that allows you to organise your code efficiently.

Objects are defined in a few distinct parts. Looking at an object from a top-down perspective:

  • Class

    • Variables of object
    • Object constructor
    • Functions

A class is simply a way to define an object, or perhaps more intuitively a set of objects (think of yourself as a particular human, in this case, you’re the object and the class is ‘_humans_). From the class, objects can be produced using the constructor which defines which variables should be set externally through parameters (for example position etc). Variables just keep track of the data in the object. Functions take care of functionality…

class Name {

  //data
  float var1;
  float var2;

  Name(temp_parameters) {
    var1 = var1_;
    var2 = var2_;
    // var2_ is the parameter which is then set as var2.
  }
}

The nice thing with objects is that you can create a whole host of instances (objects that have been defined) using arrays.

// Define the objects
object[] objects = new object[num_of_objects];

for (int i = 0; i < objects.length; i++) {
  // Initilize the objects
  objects[i] = new object(parameters);
}

while (true) {
  // Loop and perform a function on all the objects
  for (int i = 0; i < objects.length; i++) {
    objects[i].function();
  }
}

TRANSFORMATIONS

Transformations are carried out by moving the origin using the translate() function, translate(x,y) moves the origin by x to the right and y down. Rotate is used to spin the canvas around the origin clockwise: rotate(x) will rotate the canvas by x radians.
